Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>>I wonder whether in JUnit has the feature to record
>>the performance of my classes ?
>>
> 
> If you have strong requirement, JUnit is not the tool (IMO) to use to
> precisely measure performances.
> 
> You have to look at stress tools, not test tools.
> 


Agreed, you lose some precision when testing performance through the 
JUnit framework.  However, it's sometimes valuable to codify the 
expected performance results for certain test cases (or test case 
methods) in a JUnit test decorator.  The benefit of this approach is 
that you can run the tests as part of continuous integration without 
having to manually check the results.

Ideally, the performance-related tests are assembled into a performance 
test suite such that these types of tests can be run independent of the 
non-performance tests.  Running performance tests will undoubtedly slow 
down your refactoring speed, but they are candidates for the offline and 
unattended continuous integration test.
